questions.question_text:
Examine the data in the CUST_NAME column of the CUSTOMERS table:

//IMG//


You want to display the CUST_NAME values where the last name starts with Mc or MC.

Which two WHERE clauses give the required result? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Tested. Correct answers are A e D.

comments.content:
Sorry, TYPO.

A and D*

A. WHERE UPPER (SUBSTR (cust_name, INSTR (cust_name, ' ') + 1)) LIKE UPPER ('MC%')
D. WHERE INITCAP(SUBSTR(cust_name, INSTR(cust_name, ' ') +1)) LIKE 'Mc%'

i think so too
F is true - i tested it
BC are false
A is true, but you have to add it to 
ALTER TABLE <table_mame> SET unused (<column_name>) CASCADE CONSTRAINTS;
before you drop unused constraints
E should be wrong, could not find a way to undo this with roll back, this seems already the case if it is set to unused

discussion.content: It should be A, D and F.

Selected Answer: ADF
Drop column cannot be rolled back

Selected Answer: ADF
A - TRUE; e.g. ALTER TABLE departments DROP COLUMN deptno CASCADE CONSTRAINTS; 
B - FALSE; In Oracle Database 19c, the space occupied by an unused column is automatically reclaimed when the row containing that column is next updated. The space is released and becomes available for reuse within the block. 
C - FALSE; see B 
D - TRUE; partition key column cannot be dropped. When an attempt to drop the column is made, an error "ORA-12984: cannot drop partitioning column" occurs. 
E - TRUE; ALTER TABLE documentation says "Until you actually drop these columns, they continue to count toward the absolute limit of 1000 columns in a single table."

comments.content:
I am sorry, last two options are
E - FALSE; DDL commands cannot be rolled back
F - TRUE; ALTER TABLE documentation says "Until you actually drop these columns, they continue to count toward the absolute limit of 1000 columns in a single table."

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADF
D is correct, partition table will not work otherwise
Same with A and F

A is correct 
B is correct 
F is correct : Unused columns count against the 1000-column limit for tables in an Oracle database. The total count of columns that count against this limit can be obtained by getting a count from DBA_TAB_COLS

Selected Answer: ADF
B is not correct, once, the data remains in the table, but not available for querying.

Selected Answer: ADF
ADF is correct

Selected Answer: ADF
Its ADF

Selected Answer: ADF
A and D and F
A, D and F
A,D,F is correct
A,D e F

F is true
Unused Columns Count against 1000-column Table Limit Causing ORA-01792 on Compressed Table (Doc ID 2259600.1)

Is B really correct?

According to:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/admin/managing-tables.html#GUID-29CA8FDC-55FB-4BEF-AE4A-5D1B4D2BE1E1

"The ALTER TABLE...DROP UNUSED COLUMNS statement is the only action allowed on unused columns. It physically removes unused columns from the table and reclaims disk space. "

choices.B: An UNUSED column's space is reclaimed automatically when the block containing that column is next queried.
choices.E: A DROP COLUMN command can be rolled back
choices.D: Partition key columns cannot be dropped.
choices.C: An UNUSED column's space is reclaimed automatically when the row containing that column is next queried.
choices.F: A column that is set to UNUSED still counts towards the limit of 1000 columns per table
choices.A: A primary key column referenced by another column as a foreign key can be dropped if using the CASCADE option.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about dropping and unused columns in an Oracle database? (Choose three.)

choices.A: Temporary segments are only stored in a temporary tablespace.
choices.E: Table segments always have two or more extents.
choices.C: Undo segments are only stored in an undo tablespace.
choices.B: Index segments always have two or more extents.
choices.D: Cluster segments may contain data from multiple tables.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about segment types in an Oracle Database? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Answer should be AD

Why C is incorrect:
When the database instance starts, the database automatically selects the first available undo tablespace. If no undo tablespace is available, then the instance starts without an undo tablespace and stores undo records in the SYSTEM tablespace

https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/admin/managing-undo.html#GUID-281C5BFE-BAED-47C3-BFF7-806C0954F3EC

questions.question_text: Which three tasks are performed by background processes in an Oracle database instance? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
A: DBWn (Database Write process)
D: LGWR (Log Write process)
E: LREG (Listener Registration process)

I would say B is performed by server but not background process and same for C

Selected Answer: ABD
Provided answer should be correct

comments.content:
A. Database Writer process
B. Server Process
D. Log Writer process

choices.B: reading database blocks into the buffer cache
choices.E: registering services with Oracle Net listeners
choices.A: writing dirty database block images from the buffer cache
Rows inserted into a table using a view are retained in the table if the view is dropped.
choices.F: A view can be created that refers to a non-existent table in its defining query.
choices.E: A SELECT statement cannot contain a WHERE clause when querying a view containing a WHERE clause in its defining query.
choices.B: Views can join tables only if they belong to the same schema.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about views in an Oracle Database? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADF
A: true : a view is a logical structure that refers to tables, so it will not impact the underlying table
B: false
C: false : a view has an object number and is referenced in the data dictionary (there will be an entry in DBA_OBJECTS for instance)
D: true : think of a view as a stored query based on underlying tables, it does not store any data, so no need for segment
E: false
F: true : the view WILL be create, however it will return an error message when querying it
